chapters.title: Chapter 18
chapters.content:
We went on our first date.

She picked me up at my house. She was driving an old pickup truck that looked like it belonged in a museum. It was painted bright yellow with flowers on the doors.

"Where are we going?" I asked.

"You'll see," she said.

She drove us out of town, into the desert. The sun was setting, painting the sky orange and pink and purple. Saguaro cacti stood like sentinels along the road.

She parked at the top of a hill. Below us, the desert stretched out in every direction. The sky was enormous.

We sat on the hood of the truck and watched the sunset. She pointed out the first stars as they appeared.

"That's why I call myself Stargirl," she said. "I love the stars. They make me feel small. But in a good way. Like I'm part of something bigger."

I looked at her. In the fading light, she was beautiful. More beautiful than I had ever realized.

"Why me?" I asked. "Why did you pick me?"

She thought about it. "I saw you," she said finally. "Really saw you. And I liked what I saw."

"What did you see?"

She smiled. "Someone who's afraid to be himself. But who might be brave enough, someday."

I didn't know what to say to that. So I said nothing. We just sat there, watching the stars come out, one by one.

quiz.question: Where did Stargirl take Leo on their first date?
options: To the desert to watch the sunset

quiz.question: Why did Stargirl say she calls herself Stargirl?
options: Because she loves stars and feeling part of something bigger

chapters.title: Chapter 19
chapters.content:
We were together. Officially.

Word spread fast. Leo Borlock was dating Stargirl Caraway. The most normal guy in school was dating the weirdest girl in school.

People didn't know what to make of it. Some thought it was sweet. Some thought it was crazy. Some thought I had lost my mind.

Kevin was supportive. "She's good for you," he said. "She makes you different."

"Different how?" I asked.

"Better," he said. "Looser. More alive."

He was right. When I was with Stargirl, I felt like anything was possible. I felt like I could be anyone. Do anything.

She showed me her enchanted place—a spot in the desert where she went to meditate. She taught me to listen to the silence. To feel the earth beneath me. To notice the small things.

She showed me her happy wagon—a little red wagon she pulled around, filled with things to give away. Cookies for neighbors. Cards for strangers. Small gifts for anyone who looked like they needed cheering up.

She kept a notebook she called her "happy file," filled with newspaper clippings about good things that happened to people.

She saw the world differently than I did. She saw beauty where I saw ordinary. She saw possibility where I saw limits.

Being with her was like seeing the world through new eyes.

I was falling in love. And for the first time in my life, I didn't care what anyone thought.

options: A spot in the desert for meditation

options: A red wagon filled with things to give away

chapters.title: Chapter 20
chapters.content:
The basketball team was on a winning streak.

Game after game, they won. The school was excited. Mica had never been good at sports. But this year, everything was different.

And Stargirl was at every game. Cheering. Dancing. Playing her ukulele.

She cheered for both teams, as always. When the opposing team made a good shot, she clapped. When an opposing player fell down, she ran over to make sure he was okay.

At first, this had annoyed people. But now, with the team winning, nobody seemed to mind. They were too happy to care.

"She's our good luck charm," the players said. "We can't win without her."

But there was a problem.

One of the games was against Glendale. It was a close game. Very close. In the final minutes, a Glendale player went down with an injury. The crowd cheered.

But not Stargirl. She ran onto the court and knelt beside the injured player. She held his hand. She talked to him softly.

The crowd went silent. The players stood still. Everyone watched.

The Glendale player was carried off the court. Stargirl walked back to the stands. The game resumed. Mica won.

But something had changed. People were looking at Stargirl differently now. Some with admiration. Some with confusion.

And some with anger.

chapters.title: Chapter 21
chapters.content:
The team made it to the state championship.

The whole town was excited. Mica had never made it this far. People were talking about it everywhere—in stores, in restaurants, on the streets.

The championship game was against Sun Valley. They were undefeated. They were huge. They were intimidating.

The game was close. Back and forth. Our team would score, then their team would score. The crowd was on the edge of their seats.

Stargirl cheered for both teams, as always. But this time, people minded. This was the championship. This was everything.

"Stop cheering for them!" someone yelled at her.

"Whose side are you on?" yelled another.

But Stargirl didn't stop. She kept cheering. For both teams. For everyone.

In the final seconds, Sun Valley scored. They won by one point.

Mica lost.

The crowd went silent. Then they turned to Stargirl.

"This is your fault," someone said.

"You jinxed us," said another.

"Traitor."

I stood there, watching. I wanted to defend her. I wanted to tell them they were wrong. But I didn't. I was too shocked. Too scared.

Stargirl walked out of the gym alone. I didn't follow her.

I should have followed her. But I didn't.

That was the beginning of the end.

chapters.title: Chapter 22
chapters.content:
The shunning began.

It started slowly. People stopped talking to Stargirl. They stopped sitting near her. They stopped acknowledging her existence.

At first, it was just a few people. Then more. Then everyone.

The Stargirl Effect was over. The long skirts disappeared. The ribbons came out of hair. The random acts of kindness stopped.

People who had imitated her now pretended they never had. People who had admired her now acted like they didn't know her.

She was invisible. She was nothing. She was erased.

And it spread to me too.

People stopped talking to me. They stopped inviting me to things. They stopped looking at me.

"It's because of her," Kevin said. "They're punishing you because you're with her."

"What should I do?" I asked.

"I don't know," he said. "But something. You have to do something."

I knew he was right. I couldn't take it. The silence. The isolation. The feeling of being erased.

I wasn't strong like Stargirl. I needed other people. I needed to belong.

I was starting to crack.

chapters.title: Chapter 23
chapters.content:
I went to see Archie.

Archie Brubaker was a retired paleontologist who lived in town. He was wise. He knew things. Kids went to him for advice.

I told him about Stargirl. About the shunning. About how I felt.

"She's different," I said. "Too different. She doesn't fit in."

"And that's a problem?" Archie asked.

"Yes," I said. "People don't like different. They want normal."

Archie nodded. "That's true. Most people are afraid of different. They want everyone to be the same."

"So what should I do?"

He looked at me for a long time. "What do you want?" he asked.

"I want to be with her," I said. "But I also want to be accepted. I want both."

"You can't have both," he said. "Not with her. She's too unique. Too herself. The world isn't ready for her."

"So I have to choose?"

"You have to choose," he confirmed. "Between her and them. Between being different and fitting in."

I sat there, thinking. It seemed like an impossible choice. How could I give up either one?

But deep down, I think I already knew what I would choose. I already knew which way I would go.

And it filled me with shame.

chapters.title: Chapter 24
chapters.content:
I asked her to change.

We were at her enchanted place in the desert. The sun was setting. The sky was beautiful. But I couldn't enjoy it.

"You have to be more normal," I said.

She looked at me. "Normal?"

"Yes. Normal. Like everyone else. Stop singing to people. Stop wearing weird clothes. Stop cheering for the other team. Just... fit in."

She was quiet for a long time. When she finally spoke, her voice was sad.

"You want me to be someone else," she said.

"No," I said. "I want you to be... less you."

As soon as I said it, I knew how terrible it sounded. But it was too late to take it back.

She nodded slowly. "Okay," she said.

"Okay?"

"I'll try," she said. "For you. I'll try to be normal."

I should have felt happy. I should have felt relieved. But I didn't. I felt like I had just done something terrible. Something unforgivable.

I had asked the most extraordinary person I knew to become ordinary. I had asked a star to stop shining.

And she had agreed. For me.

What kind of person does that? What kind of person asks someone to give up who they are?

The answer was clear: me. I was that kind of person.

And I hated myself for it.

quiz.question: What did Leo ask Stargirl to do?
options: To be more normal and fit in

chapters.title: Chapter 25
chapters.content:
She became Susan.

The next day at school, Stargirl was gone. In her place was Susan Caraway. Just Susan. Normal Susan.

She wore regular clothes. Jeans. A plain shirt. No long skirts. No ribbons. No flowers.

She didn't carry her ukulele. She didn't have Cinnamon on her shoulder. She didn't sing or dance or cheer for the other team.

She was quiet. She was ordinary. She was invisible.

People noticed. Of course they noticed.

"What happened to Stargirl?" they asked.

"She's gone," I said. "This is Susan now."

They looked at her. They looked at me. They shrugged.

But they didn't start talking to us. They didn't stop shunning us. Nothing changed.

Susan tried harder. She tried to join conversations. She tried to laugh at jokes. She tried to be like everyone else.

But it wasn't working. People still avoided her. People still avoided me.

I had taken away everything that made her special. And it hadn't made any difference. We were still outsiders.

I watched her trying to fit in, and I felt sick. This wasn't the girl I had fallen in love with. This was a shadow. A ghost.

I had killed Stargirl. And Susan was what was left.

What had I done?

chapters.title: Chapter 26
chapters.content:
The Ocotillo Ball was coming.

It was the biggest dance of the year. Everyone went. Everyone dressed up. Everyone had a date.

Susan wanted to go. She wanted to go as a normal girl, with a normal date, doing normal things.

"Will you take me?" she asked.

"Of course," I said.

She smiled. It was a Susan smile, not a Stargirl smile. Smaller. Dimmer. Less bright.

She bought a regular dress. Not a long flowing thing with embroidery. Just a simple dress from a department store.

She did her hair in a normal way. No ribbons. No braids. Just a simple ponytail.

She looked pretty. But she didn't look like herself.

The night of the dance, I picked her up at her house. Her parents were there. They seemed confused. They kept looking at her like they didn't recognize her.

I understood. I didn't recognize her either.

We drove to the school in silence. I kept glancing at her, looking for Stargirl. But she wasn't there. Only Susan.

"Are you okay?" I asked.

"I'm fine," she said. But her voice was flat. Empty.

We pulled into the parking lot. Music was playing inside. Lights were flashing. People were laughing.

"Ready?" I asked.

She took a deep breath. "Ready," she said.

We walked in together.

chapters.title: Chapter 27
chapters.content:
The dance was a disaster. At least for us.

We walked in, and nobody noticed. Nobody said hello. Nobody acknowledged our existence.

We stood by the punch bowl. We watched others dance. We waited for someone to talk to us.

No one did.

Susan kept smiling. Kept trying. She would wave at people. They would look away. She would try to join conversations. They would end.

I could see her breaking. Piece by piece. Her smile was getting smaller. Her eyes were getting sadder.

"Let's dance," I said.

We went to the dance floor. We danced together. Just the two of us, surrounded by people who pretended we weren't there.

And then something happened.

Someone announced the king and queen of the Ocotillo Ball.

"The queen is... Susan Caraway!"

Susan froze. I froze. Everyone froze.

Then she walked to the stage. Slowly. Uncertain. The crowd parted for her, but not out of respect. Out of avoidance.

She stood on the stage. They put a crown on her head. She looked out at the crowd.

And I could see it in her eyes. The realization. This wasn't acceptance. This was something else. Something cruel.

But she didn't run. She didn't cry. She just stood there, wearing her crown, looking at all those faces that refused to look back at her.

chapters.title: Chapter 28
chapters.content:
Then something magical happened.

The band started playing a bunny hop. Susan was still on the stage, still wearing her crown. She looked lost. Defeated.

And then she started to dance.

Not a Susan dance. A Stargirl dance. Wild. Free. Uninhibited.

She kicked off her shoes. She let down her hair. She twirled and spun and leaped.

The crowd watched. At first they laughed. Then they stopped laughing. Then they started to move.

One person joined her. Then another. Then another.

Soon the whole dance floor was moving. Everyone was doing the bunny hop. Everyone was dancing with Stargirl.

Because that's who she was again. Not Susan. Stargirl.

She had come back. In that moment, on that dance floor, she had come back.

I stood on the sidelines, watching. I should have been out there with her. I should have been dancing beside her.

But I wasn't. I was too scared. Too worried about what people would think.

She danced and danced. The whole gym was alive with movement and music and joy.

And then she looked at me. Across the crowded dance floor, she looked at me.

And I saw it in her eyes. Sadness. Disappointment. Goodbye.

She turned and danced out the door. I never saw her again.

chapters.title: Chapter 29
chapters.content:
She was gone.

The next day, her desk was empty. The day after that, still empty. And the day after that.

I went to her house. No one answered. The curtains were drawn. The yellow pickup truck was gone.

I asked around. Nobody knew anything. Nobody had seen her. Nobody knew where she went.

It was like she had never existed. Like she had been a dream. A beautiful, impossible dream.

I went to Archie's house.

"She's gone," I told him.

He nodded. "I know."

"Where did she go?"

"I don't know," he said. "But wherever she is, she's being Stargirl. That's all she knows how to be."

"Will she come back?"

He looked at me sadly. "I don't think so, Leo. She gave you a gift. She showed you what it means to be free. To be yourself. What you do with that gift is up to you."

I didn't feel like I had received a gift. I felt like I had lost something precious. Something irreplaceable.

I walked home slowly. The streets felt empty. The world felt gray.

Stargirl was gone. And it was my fault.

chapters.title: Chapter 30
chapters.content:
Life went on.

School continued. People talked. People laughed. People forgot.

Within weeks, it was like Stargirl had never existed. Her name stopped being mentioned. The long skirts disappeared for good. The random acts of kindness stopped.

Everyone went back to normal. Everyone went back to being the same.

Everyone except me.

I couldn't forget her. I couldn't stop thinking about her. I saw her everywhere—in the hallways, in the courtyard, in the desert sunset.

I kept her gifts. The flower. The origami crane. The notes. I kept them in a box in my closet, next to my uncle's porcupine necktie.

Some nights I would take them out and look at them. I would read her notes. I would remember.

And I would wonder: Where was she now? What was she doing? Was she happy?

I hoped she was happy. I hoped she had found a place where she could be herself. A place where people appreciated her. A place where she didn't have to change.

I hoped she had found what I was too afraid to give her.

Acceptance. Love. Freedom to be who she was.

I had failed her. I knew that. I would carry that knowledge with me forever.

But maybe, somewhere out there, she had found someone who wouldn't fail her. Someone braver than me.

chapters.title: Chapter 31
chapters.content:
Years passed.

I graduated from high school. I went to college. I got a job. I moved away from Mica.

But I never forgot Stargirl.

She was always there, in the back of my mind. A memory. A lesson. A reminder of what I had lost.

I dated other girls. Some were nice. Some were pretty. Some were smart. But none of them were Stargirl.

None of them made me feel the way she did. None of them showed me the world the way she did. None of them were as brave, as free, as wonderfully strange.

I often wondered what happened to her. I looked for her sometimes—on the internet, in phone books, in random crowds. But I never found her.

It was like she had vanished. Like she had returned to the stars she was named for.

Kevin and I stayed in touch. We talked about her sometimes.

"You know," he said once, "I think she changed us. All of us. Even if we don't remember it."

"What do you mean?" I asked.

"I mean, we're all a little different because of her. A little braver. A little kinder. A little more willing to be ourselves."

I thought about that. Maybe he was right. Maybe Stargirl had left something behind after all.

Maybe her gift was bigger than I realized.

chapters.title: Chapter 32
chapters.content:
I went back to Mica once.

It was years later. I was passing through on a business trip. I decided to stop and see the old places.

I drove past the high school. It looked smaller than I remembered. I drove past the gym where she had danced. Past the courtyard where she had read her books.

I drove out to the desert, to her enchanted place. I sat there as the sun went down, watching the sky turn colors.

I thought about her. About us. About what might have been.

If I had been braver. If I had cared less about what people thought. If I had danced with her instead of watching from the sidelines.

Would things have been different? Would she still be here?

I would never know. That was my punishment. That was my regret.

I drove to Archie's house. He was old now, but still sharp. Still wise.

"Do you ever hear from her?" I asked.

"Sometimes," he said. "A postcard here and there. From different places."

"Is she happy?"

He smiled. "She's Stargirl. She's always happy."

I nodded. That was good. That was all I needed to know.

I left Mica that night. I never went back.

chapters.title: Chapter 33
chapters.content:
And then, on my birthday, I received a package.

There was no return address. Just my name and address, written in handwriting I didn't recognize.

I opened it carefully. Inside was a box. And inside the box was a porcupine necktie.

Not my uncle's necktie. A new one. But almost identical. The same colors. The same style. The same porcupine.

There was a note:

"Happy birthday. I never forgot."

No signature. But I knew. I knew who it was from.

She had remembered. After all these years. She had remembered my story about my uncle Pete. She had remembered me.

I sat there, holding the necktie, tears streaming down my face.

She was out there somewhere. Still thinking of others. Still giving gifts. Still being Stargirl.

I put on the necktie. It fit perfectly.

I looked at myself in the mirror. And for the first time in years, I smiled. A real smile. A Stargirl smile.

She had given me one more gift. One more reminder.

Be brave. Be yourself. Be like the stars.

Shine.

chapters.title: Epilogue: More Than Stars
chapters.content:
I still have the necktie.

Both of them, actually. My uncle Pete's and the one from Stargirl. I keep them together in a drawer, side by side.

Sometimes I take them out and look at them. Two porcupine neckties. Two gifts from people who understood something I'm still trying to learn.

Be different. Be yourself. Don't be afraid.

I'm older now. Wiser, maybe. I understand things I didn't understand back then. I see things I missed.

Stargirl wasn't weird. She wasn't crazy. She was awake. She was alive. She was everything the rest of us were too scared to be.

She saw the world as it could be, not as it was. She saw people as they could be, not as they were. She believed in the best of everyone, including me.

Especially me.

I let her down. I know that. I'll always know that. But I also know that she forgave me. The necktie proved that.

She forgave me. And maybe, someday, I'll learn to forgive myself.

In the meantime, I try to live the way she would have wanted. I try to be brave. I try to be kind. I try to notice the things that matter.

I try to be a little more like Stargirl every day.

And when I look up at the night sky, I smile. Because I know she's out there somewhere, dancing under the stars.

My Stargirl. My forever star.

More than stars.
